data.stimulus:
Read the following descriptions of QUOTING, PARAPHRASING & SUMMARISING, then complete the grid below by selecting the form by deciding which form (or forms) is being described.

We can use ideas from sources in our assignments by quoting, paraphrasing, or summarising. Quoting is using the exact words and phrases from the source. However, paraphrasing and summarising involve putting ideas in your own words, to demonstrate understanding of the text. Whichever you use, supporting your ideas with referenced sources makes your writing more credible. In order to avoid plagiarism, you need to make sure you do this correctly.

What are the differences?

Quoting

  • involves copying short sentences or passages from the original text word-for-word
  • places copied wording within “quotation marks” 
  • includes an in-text citation using the expected formatting style (APA, MLA, etc.)

Paraphrasing

  • involves putting a section of a text into your own words
  • changes the words and phrasing of the original text, but keeps the original meaning of the text
  • includes an in-text citation using the expected formatting style (APA, MLA, etc.)

Summarising

  • involves stating the main ideas and findings of a text into your own words
  • presents a general overview, so is usually much shorter than the original text
  • includes an in-text citation using the expected formatting style (APA, MLA, etc.)
